Austin's creative community has built a.question: Austin's creative community has built a strong foundation of existing organizations that informs ACME's goals and mission. How do you believe ACME should better support these organizations and cul...
sample_responses: Meet with cultural leaders regularly, document reported needs, and take actions to create equitable programs that support small and medium-sized organizations that serve historically marginalized communities that have been negatively impacted by overdevelopment, and the priorities of a few major arts venues that do not meet or represent the cultural needs of all residents.

Hello, I am unsure as to how the strong foundation of existing organizations has been built, as I direct a nonprofit organization, and I have not been reached out to by the office. None of my peers have been reached out to by the office. I believe ACME should better support organizations and cultural leaders by starting there--reaching out to us. Creating opportunities for collective voice. Getting to know the community and building trust with us, before proposing changes to the funding structure, is imperative if you plan to serve us.

Take their suggestions seriously, and encourage/incentivize them to focus more on community outreach (gathering community feedback, attending community events, helping to spread word about community events).

Funding local nonprofits and arts organizations, especially those that provide free and accessible opportunities to the community, is essential, especially in these times of diminishing federal funding.
Consistent communication, consistent funding, comprehensive understanding of issues and commitment to prioritizing and solving without politicizing.

What improvements would you like to see.question: What improvements would you like to see in these cultural funding programs?
sample_responses:
Experienced leadership and panelists in literary arts. 
A safeguard system for review when scores are irregular, which might be a red flag for a bigger issue during the panel process. 
More transparency in the process from design to implementation. 
Extended multi-year funding (longer than 2 years for Thrive) for small to medium-sized organizations growing to institution status.

I would like to see these programs become more accessible and equitable, not less. ACME's proposed changes to the current funding structure would be detrimental to Austin organizations and artists. The proposal to instate a 50% match, a required year off from funding, funding caps based on the organization's operating budget, and requirement to either be a nonprofit or fiscally sponsored to receive funding are all greatly prohibitive to equitable access. Reintroducing these outdated grant practices would, essentially, remove funding from the majority of organizations and artists who are currently building capacity thanks to these new programs, and put it in the hands of the few large institutions who already dominate the scene. I believe this would be more detrimental to organizations like ours than if we had never received the funding at all, as we would be forced to lay off staff, cut programming, and decrease hourly pay for artists. I urge you to pause this anonymous working group, and connect with the community before moving your suggestions forward to Council.

Application criteria and wording in the application/eligibility materials that encourages organizations serving multiple racial/ethnic demographics (rather than a singular racial/ethnic demographic) to apply for funding, especially if the organization is providing equitable services on the basis of very real inequities, such as age, disability, and/or income. For example, organizations that provide meaningful educational arts, music, or dance classes to low-income populations, whose demographics may or may not be tied to a single majority ethnic or racial identity and who, because of economic disadvantages, may not be able to access these programs otherwise. As of now, the grant’s language (regarding eligibility, application questions, and the rubric) is structured so that it favors organizations serving a singular racial/ethnic identity established by founders representing a singular racial/ethnic identity. But other inequalities, such as poverty, age, and/or disability, impact all racial/ethnic identities. Can organizations addressing these important issues also qualify for this grant? And if this is too far from the intent of the cultural funding grants, can we rethink the allocation of city funding so that there are other opportunities to support the broad spectrum of arts organizations doing important work in our community?

________
Space/Venue Support: Is there a way that the grant could automatically include waiver of the space rental fees for a COA venue? If grant recipients wish to hold their events in a city venue, they are essentially paying for use of city facilities with city funding. 

_______
Marketing Support: Is there a way the grant could automatically include waiver of the fees associated with paid promotional marketing packages through VisitAustin? The required calendar listing on VisitAustin website doesn’t necessarily provide a significant impact in the marketing visibility for awardees’ activities. To get beneficial visibility on the VisitAustin platform, you need to sign up for one of the paid promotional packages. As it stands now, if grant recipients wish to get the most benefit from this platform, they are essentially required to use city funding to pay for services from a city-funded organization.

_________
Availability of city venues: Is there a way grant recipients can have more equitable access (and perhaps even given more priority) to being able to schedule their events in city venues? As of now, you cannot reserve venues controlled by Austin Parks and Rec more than six months in advance, which is a huge limitation to planning/marketing/promotion of tourism events. And Palmer Events Center is nearly unattainable with the amount of events that are scheduled there, now especially with the closure of Austin Convention Center.  (BTW-Did you know the same Vintage/Garage Sale event has reserved large hall space at Palmer Events Center one weekend out of every single month for at least the past 12 consecutive months and into the next year? This recurring event, with little value in terms of representing the Austin arts and creative community as it focuses on the re-sell of secondhand goods, prevents other organizations from being able to host their events at one of the most affordable large venues in Austin. Since this is a city-owned, taxpayer-funded space, should there perhaps be a limit on the number of weekends the same event/organization can reserve this space?)
Providing more clarity on funding priorities for the the City and ways that organizations can address perceived gaps.

Consistency, fair standards, clear communication of priorities and values. No funding limits year to year (i.e. no imposed breaks in funding), no rule that groups with an evaluator on panel cannot receive funding.

What barriers do you or your community f.question: What barriers do you or your community face in accessing support or services related to arts, culture, music, and entertainment?
sample_responses: Literary arts are the least funded of the arts locally and nationally. Torch Literary Arts supports Black women writers and the larger literary community as a global resource and destination rooted in Austin, TX. Black feminist led and serving nonprofits receive less than half of one percent of global funding. A third of our community members report annual household incomes of less than $25,000. 75% of publishing and literary organizations are white and on the East Coast. This means without local sustained access to literary organizations that meet the creative and professional needs of Black women writers, our voices and literary contributions are under threat of erasure in Austin.

Honestly, threats to our funding like ACME's proposed changes to the CAD structure is our biggest concern right now. If Austin wants to be the progressive city that we claim to be, it would continue to support arts organizations amid the federal and state cuts to funding that are threatening our existence. Having to advocate to keep the support that we were given is a tremendous barrier to the daily work that we need to do to run our organization and create art for Austin. I hope that ACME leadership can back track this proposal, and become accessible to the community.

- access to affordable space
- excessive fees and stipulations to book city-owned venues 
- For example, why is it not allowed (and we were told non-negotiable) to use catering options outside the exclusive in-house catering business $$$ at Palmer Events Center? Their prices are congruent with those of a five-star hotel, with a far more limited menu. These are the types of rates and requirements that prevent many smaller local organizations from being able to access and make use of these city-owned spaces effectively.
- Another example: Did you know that booking space at city-owned recreation centers costs more than $200 per hour? On top of the flat, non-negotiable hourly rate of $155 per hour, fees for additional staff, custodial services, and utilities are added at the discretion of the venue. This makes rental rates higher than private venues in some cases.
- Another example of lack of access: Certain city-owned spaces, categorized as special event spaces (e.g. the Pavilion near Fiesta Gardens), have caps on the number of events that can be hosted there each year. Therefore, the space lies vacant most of the year, and the events that are hosted are already "grandfathered" in as one of the limited number of "special events" that can take place there. There is no way to reserve and host an event in these spaces, even small events that wouldn't have nearly the number of attendees as one of the prioritized larger special events. This blocks smaller organizations from accessing some of the most flexible and affordable city-owned spaces in Austin.

Not as much emphasis or priority focused on the literary arts and literacy advocacy, which is increasingly important in these times when public education in Texas is facing new funding challenges and subpar literacy rates are an ongoing risk.
Venue availability and affordability, consistent funding support

What kinds of programs or services would.question: What kinds of programs or services would you like ACME to offer that currently do not exist or are underrepresented?
sample_responses:
Financial support for small and medium-sized organizations to lease and grow long-term spaces. 
A transparent and equitable program with an application process for the $1 lease contract between art nonprofits, developers, and the city that few organizations enjoy. https://glasstire.com/2024/10/20/dorf-gallery-moves-to-new-location-signs-contract-for-1-annual-rent/

Again, since the ACME team has not contacted me or my peers, I am unclear on what the Office is currently doing other than working to dismantle the current CAD funding system. I think it would be best to start with connecting with the community.

Providing more opportunities for paid revenue services for local artists/performers, nonprofits, and organizations that are already doing the work that the city wants to provide to residents and community members. Use city funds to hire local artists/performers and outsource programming to local organizations. 

Provide free space (or at least more affordable rates and equitable access to space) in city-owned venues for local organizations to host their own programs. The Creative Space Assistance program as it currently stands is NOT helpful or accessible, especially considering the monetary value of "assistance" the program offers---the application is overly complicated and requires a copious amount of specific details and logistical commitments (dates/times) without any guarantee of actually being awarded use of the space.
City funding diversification away from HOT.  Increased city/community/artist partnerships, facilitated and/or supported by the City.
Would love for the literary arts to get more love!

Do you have any additional ideas, concer.question: Do you have any additional ideas, concerns, or feedback you would like to share to help ACME better serve the public?
sample_responses: I would like to support, but I was informed that being on the focus group meant your organization could not apply for city funding for the next two years. Torch Literary Arts and our community cannot afford a loss of potential funding, especially with the federal cuts and limited funding options for Black cultural arts organizations.

I am so excited that ACME was developed, and I think it can make a great difference in the lives of artists here in Austin, if that's what it sets out to do. I look forward to connecting with you all, and seeing ACME build trust with the community.

I appreciate that you're combining all these separate departments under one umbrella initiative. I hope this allows all the departments to better combine their efforts and work together to support the Austin creative community. In particular, I look forward to seeing how the Entertainment branch, with feedback from the arts, cultural arts, and music divisions, can reassess their procedures and policies regarding city-owned spaces to better support local artists and organizations.
Looking forward to ACME office getting rolling and the opportunities it will provide!  Thank you.
Thanks for Keeping Austin Creative!
